en.value: Recounting some main events in our lives - Past simple
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Maisy was born in Austin, Texas in 1953.
It's always great to be able to talk about your own life with other people. Now we're going to learn how to say:
where you were born and where you grew up
where and when you started and finished school / a job
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I started my first job when I was 16.
I [k]started[/k] my first job when I was 16.
Select the words in the correct order.
She started a new job in Krakow.
We moved to Bermuda to be closer to my grandparents.
I got a car when I was 17.
In English, the verb "to get" can have different meanings, depending on the context of the sentence. Here are a few:
to receive: I got a new phone for my birthday.
to bring: Can you get the plates from the kitchen?
Match the sentence with the right meaning of the verb "to get".
I got a new phone for my birthday.
Can you get the plates from the kitchen?
What did Mark get when he was 16?
Before we move on, let's have another look at the words we've learned:
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Christelle is asking Manuel about his life.
So, tell me about yourself, Manuel. Where are you from?
Well, I was [k]born[/k] in Portsmouth but I [k]grew up[/k] in the South of France, near Bordeaux.
That's cool. So, did you go to school in France?
Well, I [k]started[/k] school in France but then my parents moved to Switzerland, where I [k]finished[/k] school.
Oh, that sounds lovely. Very good for skiing!
Yeah, it is very beautiful there.
Well, after I [k]got my degree[/k], I had a break, and then I [k]became[/k] a programmer, moved to London, and met you!
What did Manuel do in France?
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
I finished school when I was 16 and [h]started[/h] my first job in 2006.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
After the verb "to become" you can use either a noun or an adjective.
to become + noun: I want to become a scientist.
to become + adjective: I became successful in my last job.
This means he lost his job.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
I [k]finished[/k] school in 2001 in a small village near Lucerne.
After a few years I [k]got[/k] my first job in IT.
Fill in the gap using the image.
After I finished university, I [k]became|got a job as[/k] a programmer.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
They [k]were born[/k] and grew up in Australia.
Tell the busuu community about your life using some of the words you've learned.
I was born in Botswana in Africa in 1961. We moved to Peru when I was 5. I grew up in Chile where I finished school and started my first job. I became really successful there!

We are now going to take a look at our first past tense, the past simple, which is the tense we use to talk about completed actions in the past. We've already seen the past simple in questions like, "How was your day?", but let's now take a look at how we recognise and build it.
I worked in France for a year.
We finished our degree four years ago.
This sentence talks about the past.
I moved to Australia in May.
I always study hard at university.
We often use the past simple with expressions of time.
Select the three words that form an expression of time.

We generally form the past simple with regular verbs by adding the ending "-ed". However, if the verb already ends in "-e", we just add "-d" and, if the verb ends in "-y", we remove it and add "-ied".
Select the three regular verbs in the past simple.
She [h]worked[/h] in marketing before she was a teacher.
I [h]started[/h] my first job when I was 17.
We [h]lived[/h] in Shanghai when I was younger.
They [k]wanted[/k] to go shopping on Tuesday.
To recap, let's take a look at the regular verbs we've just seen! We'll add to this list throughout the course.
Add the past simple ending to the verb.
I start[k]ed[/k] my first job in 2001.
She revise[k]d[/k] very hard for the exam.
She cooked dinner for a friend.
Listen to the dialogue. Select the most accurate statement.
Peter's day was good. He moved into his new house.
Peter's day was quite tiring. He worked all evening.
Peter had a good day. He cooked for his mum and dad.
Re-write the verb in the past simple
My parents [k]moved[/k] to Hong Kong in 2007.
Katya worked in Spain for a year.
Katya finished her degree in Spanish last year.
I [k]started[/k] my current job last year.
She [k]lived[/k] in Barcelona for four years.
